TITLE: Creating a Basic HTTP Server with Node.js (CommonJS)
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to create a simple HTTP server using Node.js with CommonJS modules. It sets up a server that listens on localhost:3000 and responds with 'Hello World' to all requests.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
const { createServer } = require('node:http');

const hostname = '127.0.0.1';
const port = 3000;

const server = createServer((req, res) => {
  res.statusCode = 200;
  res.setHeader('Content-Type', 'text/plain');
  res.end('Hello World');
});

server.listen(port, hostname, () => {
  console.log(`Server running at http://${hostname}:${port}/`);
});

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Streaming Large Files with Node.js
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to handle large files efficiently using streams, including downloading and reading files in chunks. Implements error handling and progress tracking.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
import fs from 'fs';
import path from 'path';
import { pipeline } from 'node:stream/promises';

const fileUrl = 'https://www.gutenberg.org/files/2701/2701-0.txt';
const outputFilePath = path.join(process.cwd(), 'moby.md');

async function downloadFile(url, outputPath) {
  const response = await fetch(url);

  if (!response.ok || !response.body) {
    throw new Error(`Failed to fetch ${url}. Status: ${response.status}`);
  }

  const fileStream = fs.createWriteStream(outputPath);
  console.log(`Downloading file from ${url} to ${outputPath}`);

  await pipeline(response.body, fileStream);
  console.log('File downloaded successfully');
}

async function readFile(filePath) {
  const readStream = fs.createReadStream(filePath, { encoding: 'utf8' });

  try {
    for await (const chunk of readStream) {
      console.log('--- File chunk start ---');
      console.log(chunk);
      console.log('--- File chunk end ---');
    }
    console.log('Finished reading the file.');
  } catch (error) {
    console.error(`Error reading file: ${error.message}`);
  }
}

try {
  await downloadFile(fileUrl, outputFilePath);
  await readFile(outputFilePath);
} catch (error) {
  console.error(`Error: ${error.message}`);
}

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Reading Command Line Input using CommonJS
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to create an interactive CLI program using Node.js readline module with CommonJS require syntax. The code creates a readline interface, prompts for user input, and processes the response.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
const readline = require('node:readline');

const rl = readline.createInterface({
  input: process.stdin,
  output: process.stdout,
});

rl.question(`What's your name?`, name => {
  console.log(`Hi ${name}!`);
  rl.close();
});

TITLE: Executing Node.js with File System Permissions
DESCRIPTION: Examples of using the new experimental permission flags to control file system access in Node.js 20. Shows various ways to restrict read/write access using specific paths and wildcards.

LANGUAGE: console
CODE:
$ node --experimental-permission --allow-fs-read=* --allow-fs-write=* index.js
$ node --experimental-permission --allow-fs-write=/tmp/ --allow-fs-read=/home/index.js index.js
$ node --experimental-permission --allow-fs-read=/home/test* index.js

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Using process.nextTick() for Asynchronous API Error Handling
DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates how process.nextTick() can be used to ensure asynchronous error handling in an API, even when the error is detected synchronously.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
function apiCall(arg, callback) {
  if (typeof arg !== 'string')
    return process.nextTick(
      callback,
      new TypeError('argument should be string')
    );
}

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Comparing setImmediate() and setTimeout() in Node.js
DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates the non-deterministic execution order of setImmediate() and setTimeout() when called outside an I/O cycle.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
// timeout_vs_immediate.js
setTimeout(() => {
  console.log('timeout');
}, 0);

setImmediate(() => {
  console.log('immediate');
});

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Implementing Type-Safe User Validation in TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates TypeScript type declarations and type checking with a user validation example. Shows custom type definition, function implementation with type annotations, and type inference.

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
type User = {
  name: string;
  age: number;
};

function isAdult(user: User): boolean {
  return user.age >= 18;
}

const justine = {
  name: 'Justine',
  age: 23,
} satisfies User;

const isJustineAnAdult = isAdult(justine);

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
const fs = require('node:fs');

try {
  const data = fs.readFileSync('/Users/joe/test.txt', 'utf8');
  console.log(data);
} catch (err) {
  console.error(err);
}

  console.error(err);

TITLE: Reading Files Asynchronously with Node.js fs.readFile
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to read a file asynchronously using the fs.readFile() method in both CommonJS and ES Modules formats. Includes error handling and UTF-8 encoding.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
const fs = require('node:fs');

fs.readFile('/Users/joe/test.txt', 'utf8', (err, data) => {
  if (err) {
    console.error(err);
    return;
  }
  console.log(data);
});

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
import fs from 'node:fs';

fs.readFile('/Users/joe/test.txt', 'utf8', (err, data) => {
  if (err) {
    console.error(err);
    return;
  }
  console.log(data);
});

TITLE: Writing Files with Promises using Node.js fsPromises.writeFile()
DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates how to write content to a file using the promise-based fsPromises.writeFile() method from the fs/promises module. It uses async/await syntax for handling the asynchronous operation.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
const fs = require('node:fs/promises');

async function example() {
  try {
    const content = 'Some content!';
    await fs.writeFile('/Users/joe/test.txt', content);
  } catch (err) {
    console.log(err);
  }
}

example();

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Custom Writable Stream Implementation
DESCRIPTION: Creates a writable stream that converts input to uppercase with backpressure handling using highWaterMark

LANGUAGE: cjs
CODE:
const { Writable } = require('node:stream');
const { once } = require('node:events');

class MyStream extends Writable {
  constructor() {
    super({ highWaterMark: 10 /* 10 bytes */ });
  }
  _write(data, encode, cb) {
    process.stdout.write(data.toString().toUpperCase() + '\n', cb);
  }
}

async function main() {
  const stream = new MyStream();

  for (let i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
    const waitDrain = !stream.write('hello');

    if (waitDrain) {
      console.log('>> wait drain');
      await once(stream, 'drain');
    }
  }

  stream.end('world');
}

main().catch(console.error);

LANGUAGE: mjs
CODE:
import { Writable } from 'node:stream';
import { once } from 'node:events';

class MyStream extends Writable {
  constructor() {
    super({ highWaterMark: 10 /* 10 bytes */ });
  }
  _write(data, encode, cb) {
    process.stdout.write(data.toString().toUpperCase() + '\n', cb);
  }
}
const stream = new MyStream();

for (let i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
  const waitDrain = !stream.write('hello');

  if (waitDrain) {
    console.log('>> wait drain');
    await once(stream, 'drain');
  }
}

stream.end('world');

TITLE: Configuring Security Policy for Node.js Module Resolution
DESCRIPTION: This JSON snippet shows how to configure a security policy file for Node.js to enforce integrity checks on module resolution, mitigating uncontrolled search path element vulnerabilities.

LANGUAGE: json
CODE:
{
  "resources": {
    "./app/auth.js": {
      "integrity": "sha256-iuGZ6SFVFpMuHUcJciQTIKpIyaQVigMZlvg9Lx66HV8="
    },
    "./app/server.js": {
      "dependencies": {
        "./auth": "./app/auth.js"
      },
      "integrity": "sha256-NPtLCQ0ntPPWgfVEgX46ryTNpdvTWdQPoZO3kHo0bKI="
    }
  }
}

----------------------------------------

TITLE: GitHub Action for CI Type Checking and Testing
DESCRIPTION: Sets up a CI task to automatically check types and run tests for a PR into the main branch. It includes matrix testing for different Node.js versions and operating systems.

LANGUAGE: yaml
CODE:
# yaml-language-server: $schema=https://json.schemastore.org/github-workflow.json

name: Tests

on:
  pull_request:
    branches: ['*']

jobs:
  check-types:
    # Separate these from tests because
    # they are platform and node-version independent
    # and need be run only once.

    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version-file: '.nvmrc'
          cache: 'npm'
      - name: npm clean install
        run: npm ci
      # You may want to run a lint check here too
      - run: node --run types:check

  get-matrix:
    # Automatically pick active LTS versions
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    outputs:
      latest: ${{ steps.set-matrix.outputs.requireds }}
    steps:
      - uses: ljharb/actions/node/matrix@main
        id: set-matrix
        with:
          versionsAsRoot: true
          type: majors
          preset: '>= 22' # glob is not backported below 22.x

  test:
    needs: [get-matrix]
    runs-on: ${{ matrix.os }}

    strategy:
      fail-fast: false
      matrix:
        node-version: ${{ fromJson(needs.get-matrix.outputs.latest) }}
        os:
          - macos-latest
          - ubuntu-latest
          - windows-latest

    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - name: Use node ${{ matrix.node-version }}
        uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: ${{ matrix.node-version }}
          cache: 'npm'
      - name: npm clean install
        run: npm ci
      - run: node --run test

  name: 'Justine',
  age: 23,
} satisfies User;

├ .github/
│ ├ workflows/

├ src/

│ ├ main.ts
│ ├ main.test.ts
│ ├ some-util.ts
│ └ some-util.test.ts

├ package.json
├ README.md
└ tsconfig.json

│ ├ main.ts
│ └ some-util/

│   │ └ some-util.test.ts
│   └ some-util.ts
├ LICENSE
├ package.json
├ README.md
└ tsconfig.json

TITLE: Extracting Path Information using Node.js path Module

LANGUAGE: cjs
CODE:
const path = require('node:path');

const notes = '/users/joe/notes.txt';

path.dirname(notes); // /users/joe
path.basename(notes); // notes.txt
path.extname(notes); // .txt

TITLE: Creating HTTP Server using Node.js ES Modules

CODE:
import { createServer } from 'node:http';

const hostname = '127.0.0.1';
const port = 3000;

const server = createServer((req, res) => {
  res.statusCode = 200;
  res.setHeader('Content-Type', 'text/plain');
  res.end('Hello World');
});

server.listen(port, hostname, () => {
  console.log(`Server running at http://${hostname}:${port}/`);
});

TITLE: Basic Readable Stream Implementation
DESCRIPTION: Creates a custom Readable stream that generates smiley faces, demonstrating core readable stream functionality with data events

LANGUAGE: cjs
CODE:
const { Readable } = require('node:stream');

class MyStream extends Readable {
  #count = 0;
  _read(size) {
    this.push(':-)'); 
    if (++this.#count === 5) {
      this.push(null);
    }
  }
}

const stream = new MyStream();

stream.on('data', chunk => {
  console.log(chunk.toString());
});

LANGUAGE: mjs
CODE:
import { Readable } from 'node:stream';

class MyStream extends Readable {
  #count = 0;
  _read(size) {
    this.push(':-)');
    if (++this.#count === 5) {
      this.push(null);
    }
  }
}

const stream = new MyStream();

stream.on('data', chunk => {
  console.log(chunk.toString());
});

TITLE: Creating Node.js User-Land Snapshots
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to create and use user-land snapshots using the new --build-snapshot and --snapshot-blob options. Shows writing a snapshot to a blob file and restoring application state.

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
echo "globalThis.foo = 'I am from the snapshot'" > snapshot.js
node --snapshot-blob snapshot.blob --build-snapshot snapshot.js

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
echo "console.log(globalThis.foo)" > index.js
node --snapshot-blob snapshot.blob index.js
# => I am from the snapshot

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
echo "require('v8').startupSnapshot.setDeserializeMainFunction(() => console.log('I am from the snapshot'))" > snapshot.js
node --snapshot-blob snapshot.blob --build-snapshot snapshot.js
node --snapshot-blob snapshot.blob
# => I am from the snapshot

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Avoiding Premature Variable Access with process.nextTick()
DESCRIPTION: This example shows how process.nextTick() can be used to ensure that variables are properly initialized before a callback is executed.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
let bar;

function someAsyncApiCall(callback) {
  process.nextTick(callback);
}

someAsyncApiCall(() => {
  console.log('bar', bar); // 1
});

bar = 1;

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Creating a Vulnerable TCP Server in Node.js
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to create a TCP server in Node.js that is vulnerable to Denial of Service attacks due to improper error handling. It shows both CommonJS and ES module versions of the code.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
const net = require('node:net');

const server = net.createServer(function (socket) {
  // socket.on('error', console.error) // this prevents the server to crash
  socket.write('Echo server\r\n');
  socket.pipe(socket);
});

server.listen(5000, '0.0.0.0');

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
import net from 'node:net';

const server = net.createServer(function (socket) {
  // socket.on('error', console.error) // this prevents the server to crash
  socket.write('Echo server\r\n');
  socket.pipe(socket);
});

server.listen(5000, '0.0.0.0');

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Creating HTTP Server with Node.js
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to create a basic HTTP server using Node.js that listens on localhost port 3000 and responds with 'Hello World!'

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
import { createServer } from 'node:http';

const server = createServer((req, res) => {
  res.writeHead(200, { 'Content-Type': 'text/plain' });
  res.end('Hello World!\n');
});

// starts a simple http server locally on port 3000
server.listen(3000, '127.0.0.1', () => {
  console.log('Listening on 127.0.0.1:3000');
});

// run with `node server.mjs`

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Writing Tests in Node.js
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to write basic tests using Node.js built-in test and assert modules, including both passing and failing test cases.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
import assert from 'node:assert';
import test from 'node:test';

test('that 1 is equal 1', () => {
  assert.strictEqual(1, 1);
});

test('that throws as 1 is not equal 2', () => {
  // throws an exception because 1 != 2
  assert.strictEqual(1, 2);
});

// run with `node tests.mjs`

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Demonstrating setImmediate() Precedence in I/O Cycle
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how setImmediate() callbacks are always executed before setTimeout() callbacks when scheduled within an I/O cycle.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
// timeout_vs_immediate.js
const fs = require('node:fs');

fs.readFile(__filename, () => {
  setTimeout(() => {
    console.log('timeout');
  }, 0);
  setImmediate(() => {
    console.log('immediate');
  });
});

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Serial Execution Pattern in JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: Implementation of serial execution pattern where functions are executed in strict sequential order.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
const operations = [
  { func: function1, args: args1 },
  { func: function2, args: args2 },
  { func: function3, args: args3 },
];

function executeFunctionWithArgs(operation, callback) {
  const { args, func } = operation;
  func(args, callback);
}

function serialProcedure(operation) {
  if (!operation) process.exit(0);
  executeFunctionWithArgs(operation, function (result) {
    serialProcedure(operations.shift());
  });
}

serialProcedure(operations.shift());

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Writing Unit Tests in Node.js
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates writing unit tests for a Cat class using Node.js's test runner, including tests for expected behavior and error cases.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
import assert from 'node:assert/strict';
import { describe, it } from 'node:test';

import { Cat } from './Cat.js';
import { Fish } from './Fish.js';
import { Plastic } from './Plastic.js';

describe('Cat', () => {
  it('should eat fish', () => {
    const cat = new Cat();
    const fish = new Fish();

    assert.doesNotThrow(() => cat.eat(fish));
  });

  it('should NOT eat plastic', () => {
    const cat = new Cat();
    const plastic = new Plastic();

    assert.throws(() => cat.eat(plastic));
  });
});

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Writing Files Synchronously with Node.js fs.writeFileSync()
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to write content to a file synchronously using the fs.writeFileSync() method. It uses a try-catch block for error handling.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
const fs = require('node:fs');

const content = 'Some content!';

try {
  fs.writeFileSync('/Users/joe/test.txt', content);
  // file written successfully
} catch (err) {
  console.error(err);
}

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Partitioned Average Calculation in Node.js
DESCRIPTION: Example of partitioning a CPU-intensive calculation to avoid blocking the Event Loop using asynchronous recursion.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
function asyncAvg(n, avgCB) {
  // Save ongoing sum in JS closure.
  let sum = 0;
  function help(i, cb) {
    sum += i;
    if (i == n) {
      cb(sum);
      return;
    }

    // "Asynchronous recursion".
    // Schedule next operation asynchronously.
    setImmediate(help.bind(null, i + 1, cb));
  }

  // Start the helper, with CB to call avgCB.
  help(1, function(sum) {
    let avg = sum / n;
    avgCB(avg);
  });
}

asyncAvg(n, function(avg) {
  console.log('avg of 1-n: ' + avg);
});

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Reading Command Line Input using ES Modules
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to implement an interactive CLI program using Node.js readline module with ES Module import syntax. The functionality is identical to the CommonJS version but uses modern import syntax.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
import readline from 'node:readline';

const rl = readline.createInterface({
  input: process.stdin,
  output: process.stdout,
});

rl.question(`What's your name?`, name => {
  console.log(`Hi ${name}!`);
  rl.close();
});

----------------------------------------

TITLE: JSON Performance Impact Example in Node.js
DESCRIPTION: Demonstration of how large JSON operations can block the Event Loop with stringification and parsing.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
let obj = { a: 1 };
let niter = 20;

let before, str, pos, res, took;

for (let i = 0; i < niter; i++) {
  obj = { obj1: obj, obj2: obj }; // Doubles in size each iter
}

before = process.hrtime();
str = JSON.stringify(obj);
took = process.hrtime(before);
console.log('JSON.stringify took ' + took);

before = process.hrtime();
pos = str.indexOf('nomatch');
took = process.hrtime(before);
console.log('Pure indexof took ' + took);

before = process.hrtime();
res = JSON.parse(str);
took = process.hrtime(before);
console.log('JSON.parse took ' + took);

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Basic Stream Interface Example
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates basic stream usage with readline interface in both CommonJS and ES modules formats.

LANGUAGE: cjs
CODE:
const readline = require('node:readline');

// process.stdin and process.stdout are both instances of Streams.
const rl = readline.createInterface({
  input: process.stdin,
  output: process.stdout,
});

rl.question('Why should you use streams? ', answer => {
  console.log(`Maybe it's ${answer}, maybe it's because they are awesome! :)`);

  rl.close();
});

LANGUAGE: mjs
CODE:
import readline from 'node:readline';

// process.stdin and process.stdout are both instances of Streams.

  input: process.stdin,
  output: process.stdout,
});

rl.question('Why should you use streams? ', answer => {
  console.log(`Maybe it's ${answer}, maybe it's because they are awesome! :)`);

  rl.close();

TITLE: Node.js Test Runner Example

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
import { test, mock } from 'node:test';
import assert from 'node:assert';
import fs from 'node:fs';

mock.method(fs, 'readFile', async () => 'Hello World');
test('synchronous passing test', async t => {
  // This test passes because it does not throw an exception.
  assert.strictEqual(await fs.readFile('a.txt'), 'Hello World');
});

  if (err) throw err;

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Demonstrating Timer Execution in Node.js Event Loop
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how the execution of a timer callback can be delayed by asynchronous file reading operation, illustrating the behavior of the event loop phases.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
const fs = require('node:fs');

function someAsyncOperation(callback) {
  // Assume this takes 95ms to complete
  fs.readFile('/path/to/file', callback);
}

const timeoutScheduled = Date.now();

setTimeout(() => {
  const delay = Date.now() - timeoutScheduled;

  console.log(`${delay}ms have passed since I was scheduled`);
}, 100);

// do someAsyncOperation which takes 95 ms to complete
someAsyncOperation(() => {
  const startCallback = Date.now();

  // do something that will take 10ms...
  while (Date.now() - startCallback < 10) {
    // do nothing
  }
});

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Advanced Dynamic Test Case Generation in Node.js (v23.8.0+)
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates an advanced example of dynamically generating test cases to check package.json files in workspaces using Node.js's test runner in version 23.8.0 and later.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
import assert from 'node:assert/strict';
import { test } from 'node:test';

import { getWorkspacePJSONs } from './getWorkspacePJSONs.mjs';

const requiredKeywords = ['node.js', 'sliced bread'];

test('Check package.jsons', { concurrency: true }, async t => {
  const pjsons = await getWorkspacePJSONs();

  for (const pjson of pjsons) {
    // ⚠️ `t.test`, NOT `test`
    t.test(`Ensure fields are properly set: ${pjson.name}`, () => {
      assert.partialDeepStrictEqual(pjson.keywords, requiredKeywords);
    });
  }
});

TITLE: Setting Up UI Tests in Node.js
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates the setup for UI tests in Node.js, including setting up a DOM environment with jsdom, mocking IndexedDb, and customizing global objects like history.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
import { register } from 'node:module';

// ⚠️ Ensure only 1 instance of JSDom is instantiated; multiples will lead to many 🤬
import jsdom from 'global-jsdom';

import './setup.units.mjs'; // 💡

import { IndexedDb } from './globals/IndexedDb.js';

register('some-css-modules-loader');

jsdom(undefined, {
  url: 'https://test.example.com', // ⚠️ Failing to specify this will likely lead to many 🤬
});

// Example of how to decorate a global.
// JSDOM's `history` does not handle navigation; the following handles most cases.
const pushState = globalThis.history.pushState.bind(globalThis.history);
globalThis.history.pushState = function mock_pushState(data, unused, url) {
  pushState(data, unused, url);
  globalThis.location.assign(url);
};

beforeEach(globalUIBeforeEach);
function globalUIBeforeEach() {
  globalThis.indexedDb = new IndexedDb();
}

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Parallel Execution Pattern in JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates parallel execution pattern for handling multiple asynchronous operations simultaneously.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
let count = 0;
let success = 0;
const failed = [];
const recipients = [
  { name: 'Bart', email: 'bart@tld' },
  { name: 'Marge', email: 'marge@tld' },
  { name: 'Homer', email: 'homer@tld' },
  { name: 'Lisa', email: 'lisa@tld' },
  { name: 'Maggie', email: 'maggie@tld' }
];

function dispatch(recipient, callback) {
  sendMail({
    subject: 'Dinner tonight',
    message: 'We have lots of cabbage on the plate. You coming?',
    smtp: recipient.email
  }, callback);
}

function final(result) {
  console.log(`Result: ${result.count} attempts \
      & ${result.success} succeeded emails`);
  if (result.failed.length)
    console.log(`Failed to send to: \
        \n${result.failed.join('\n')}\n`);
}

recipients.forEach(function (recipient) {
  dispatch(recipient, function (err) {
    if (!err) {
      success += 1;
    } else {
      failed.push(recipient.name);
    }
    count += 1;

    if (count === recipients.length) {
      final({
        count,
        success,
        failed
      });
    }
  });
});

TITLE: Running TypeScript with Type Transformation in Node.js

LANGUAGE: bash

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Emitting Events in Constructor using process.nextTick()
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to use process.nextTick() to safely emit an event from a constructor in a custom EventEmitter class.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
const EventEmitter = require('node:events');

class MyEmitter extends EventEmitter {
  constructor() {
    super();

    // use nextTick to emit the event once a handler is assigned
    process.nextTick(() => {
      this.emit('event');
    });
  }
}

const myEmitter = new MyEmitter();
myEmitter.on('event', () => {
  console.log('an event occurred!');
});

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Synchronous Control Flow Example in JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: Shows how control flow works with synchronous operations when data is available in memory.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
function getSong() {
  let _song = '';
  let i = 100;
  for (i; i > 0; i -= 1) {
    _song += `${i} beers on the wall, you take one down and pass it around, ${i - 1} bottles of beer on the wall\n`;
    if (i === 1) {
      _song += "Hey let's get some more beer";
    }
  }

  return _song;
}

function singSong(_song) {
  if (!_song) throw new Error("song is '' empty, FEED ME A SONG!");
  console.log(_song);
}

const song = getSong();
// this will work
singSong(song);

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Implementing User Authentication Handler in Express
DESCRIPTION: An Express route handler for authenticating users, including password verification using crypto.pbkdf2Sync and crypto.timingSafeEqual.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
app.get('/auth', (req, res) => {
  let username = req.query.username || '';
  const password = req.query.password || '';

  username = username.replace(/[!@#$%^&*]/g, '');

  if (!username || !password || !users[username]) {
    return res.sendStatus(400);
  }

  const { salt, hash } = users[username];
  const encryptHash = crypto.pbkdf2Sync(password, salt, 10000, 512, 'sha512');

  if (crypto.timingSafeEqual(hash, encryptHash)) {
    res.sendStatus(200);
  } else {
    res.sendStatus(401);
  }
});

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Promise-based File Stats in CommonJS
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to use the promise-based fs.stat() method from fs/promises module in CommonJS format using async/await syntax.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
const fs = require('node:fs/promises');

async function example() {
  try {
    const stats = await fs.stat('/Users/joe/test.txt');
    stats.isFile(); // true
    stats.isDirectory(); // false
    stats.isSymbolicLink(); // false
    stats.size; // 1024000 //= 1MB
  } catch (err) {
    console.log(err);
  }
}
example();

TITLE: Creating a New Folder in Node.js
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to create a new folder using the fs.mkdirSync() method. It first checks if the folder exists using fs.existsSync() to avoid errors.

LANGUAGE: cjs
CODE:
const fs = require('node:fs');

const folderName = '/Users/joe/test';

try {
  if (!fs.existsSync(folderName)) {
    fs.mkdirSync(folderName);
  }
} catch (err) {
  console.error(err);
}

LANGUAGE: mjs
CODE:
import fs from 'node:fs';

const folderName = '/Users/joe/test';

  if (!fs.existsSync(folderName)) {
    fs.mkdirSync(folderName);
  }
} catch (err) {
  console.error(err);
}

TITLE: Implementing Storage Operations with Database Interaction
DESCRIPTION: Defines read and save functions that interact with a database, demonstrating potential mocking targets for external systems.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
import { db } from 'db';

export function read(key, all = false) {
  validate(key, val);

  if (all) return db.getAll(key);

  return db.getOne(key);
}

export function save(key, val) {
  validate(key, val);

  return db.upsert(key, val);
}

TITLE: POST Request with Node.js Fetch
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to make a POST request with custom headers and JSON body data using the Fetch API to create a new post.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
const body = {
  title: 'foo',
  body: 'bar',
  userId: 1,
};

async function main() {
  const response = await fetch('https://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/posts', {
    method: 'POST',
    headers: {
      'User-Agent': 'undici-stream-example',
      'Content-Type': 'application/json',
    },
    body: JSON.stringify(body),
  });
  const data = await response.json();
  console.log(data);
}

main().catch(console.error);

  name: string;
  age: number;
};

  return user.age >= 18;
}

const justine: User = {
  name: 'Justine',
  age: 'Secret!',
};

const isJustineAnAdult: string = isAdult(justine, "I shouldn't be here!");

TITLE: Handling HTTP Requests in Node.js
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to handle incoming HTTP requests in Node.js. It shows how to access request properties such as method, URL, and headers, as well as how to process the request body using streams.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
const { method, url, headers } = request;
let body = [];
request
  .on('error', err => {
    console.error(err);
  })
  .on('data', chunk => {
    body.push(chunk);
  })
  .on('end', () => {
    body = Buffer.concat(body).toString();
    // At this point, we have the headers, method, url and body, and can now
    // do whatever we need to in order to respond to this request.
  });

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
path.resolve('joe.txt'); // '/Users/joe/joe.txt' if run from my home folder

path.resolve('tmp', 'joe.txt'); // '/Users/joe/tmp/joe.txt' if run from my home folder

path.resolve('/etc', 'joe.txt'); // '/etc/joe.txt'

TITLE: REDOS Vulnerable Regexp Example in Node.js
DESCRIPTION: Example showing a regular expression pattern vulnerable to exponential-time attacks that could block the Event Loop.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
app.get('/redos-me', (req, res) => {
  let filePath = req.query.filePath;

  // REDOS
  if (filePath.match(/(/.+)+$/)) {
    console.log('valid path');
  } else {
    console.log('invalid path');
  }

  res.sendStatus(200);
});

TITLE: Using File Stats Methods in CommonJS

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
const fs = require('node:fs');

fs.stat('/Users/joe/test.txt', (err, stats) => {
  if (err) {
    console.error(err);
    return;
  }

  stats.isFile(); // true
  stats.isDirectory(); // false
  stats.isSymbolicLink(); // false
  stats.size; // 1024000 //= 1MB
});

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Demonstrating Callback Hell Pattern in JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: Shows a typical example of nested callbacks that can lead to callback hell, where multiple asynchronous operations are chained together in a nested structure.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
async1(function (input, result1) {
  async2(function (result2) {
    async3(function (result3) {
      async4(function (result4) {
        async5(function (output) {
          // do something with output
        });
      });
    });
  });
});

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Mocking APIs using Undici in Node.js Tests
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to use Undici to mock the fetch API in Node.js tests, allowing for controlled testing of network requests.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
import assert from 'node:assert/strict';
import { beforeEach, describe, it } from 'node:test';
import { MockAgent, setGlobalDispatcher } from 'undici';

import endpoints from './endpoints.mjs';

describe('endpoints', { concurrency: true }, () => {
  let agent;
  beforeEach(() => {
    agent = new MockAgent();
    setGlobalDispatcher(agent);
  });

  it('should retrieve data', async () => {
    const endpoint = 'foo';
    const code = 200;
    const data = {
      key: 'good',
      val: 'item',
    };

    agent
      .get('https://example.com')
      .intercept({
        path: endpoint,
        method: 'GET',
      })
      .reply(code, data);

    assert.deepEqual(await endpoints.get(endpoint), {
      code,
      data,
    });
  });

  it('should save data', async () => {
    const endpoint = 'foo/1';
    const code = 201;
    const data = {
      key: 'good',
      val: 'item',
    };

    agent
      .get('https://example.com')
      .intercept({
        path: endpoint,
        method: 'PUT',
      })
      .reply(code, data);

    assert.deepEqual(await endpoints.save(endpoint), {
      code,
      data,
    });
  });
});

import foo from './foo.mjs';

TITLE: Programmatic GC Tracing with Node.js Performance Hooks
DESCRIPTION: Example showing how to use Node.js performance hooks to programmatically trace garbage collection events.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
const { PerformanceObserver } = require('node:perf_hooks');

// Create a performance observer
const obs = new PerformanceObserver(list => {
  const entry = list.getEntries()[0];
});

// Subscribe to notifications of GCs
obs.observe({ entryTypes: ['gc'] });

// Stop subscription
obs.disconnect();

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Promise-based File Opening in Node.js (CommonJS)
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates promise-based file handling using fs/promises module in CommonJS format. Shows proper file handle management with try/finally block.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
const fs = require('node:fs/promises');
// Or const fs = require('fs').promises before v14.
async function example() {
  let filehandle;
  try {
    filehandle = await fs.open('/Users/joe/test.txt', 'r');
    console.log(filehandle.fd);
    console.log(await filehandle.readFile({ encoding: 'utf8' }));
  } finally {
    if (filehandle) await filehandle.close();
  }
}
example();

  // Actual code of my Component
);

TITLE: Using the new zlib.crc32() function
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to use the newly exposed zlib.crc32() function to compute CRC32 checksums for data.

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
const zlib = require('node:zlib');
const { Buffer } = require('node:buffer');

let crc = zlib.crc32('hello'); // 907060870
crc = zlib.crc32('world', crc); // 4192936109

crc = zlib.crc32(Buffer.from('hello', 'utf16le')); // 1427272415
crc = zlib.crc32(Buffer.from('world', 'utf16le'), crc); // 4150509955

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Error-First Callback Pattern
DESCRIPTION: Shows the Node.js error-first callback pattern for handling errors in asynchronous operations.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
const fs = require('node:fs');

fs.readFile('/file.json', (err, data) => {
  if (err) {
    // handle error
    console.log(err);
    return;
  }

  // no errors, process data
  console.log(data);
});

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Using assert.CallTracker to track function calls in Node.js
DESCRIPTION: Example of using the new experimental assert.CallTracker API to track and verify the number of times a function is called.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
const assert = require('assert');

const tracker = new assert.CallTracker();

function func() {}
// callsfunc() must be called exactly twice before tracker.verify().
const callsfunc = tracker.calls(func, 2);
callsfunc();
callsfunc();

function otherFunc() {}
// The second parameter defaults to `1`.
const callsotherFunc = tracker.calls(otherFunc);
callsotherFunc();

// Calls tracker.verify() and verifies if all tracker.calls() functions have
// been called the right number of times.
process.on('exit', () => {
  tracker.verify();
});

----------------------------------------

TITLE: GitHub Repository Streaming with Undici
DESCRIPTION: Example of streaming API responses from GitHub using Undici's stream function and Node.js Writable streams.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
import { stream } from 'undici';
import { Writable } from 'stream';

async function fetchGitHubRepos() {
  const url = 'https://api.github.com/users/nodejs/repos';

  const { statusCode } = await stream(
    url,
    {
      method: 'GET',
      headers: {
        'User-Agent': 'undici-stream-example',
        Accept: 'application/json',
      },
    },
    () => {
      let buffer = '';

      return new Writable({
        write(chunk, encoding, callback) {
          buffer += chunk.toString();

          try {
            const json = JSON.parse(buffer);
            console.log(
              'Repository Names:',
              json.map(repo => repo.name)
            );
            buffer = '';
          } catch (error) {
            console.error('Error parsing JSON:', error);
          }

          callback();
        },
        final(callback) {
          console.log('Stream processing completed.');
          callback();
        },
      });
    }
  );

  console.log(`Response status: ${statusCode}`);
}

fetchGitHubRepos().catch(console.error);

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Reading Directory Contents in Node.js
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to read the contents of a directory using fs.readdirSync(). It includes examples of getting full file paths and filtering for files only.

LANGUAGE: cjs
CODE:
const fs = require('node:fs');

const folderPath = '/Users/joe';

fs.readdirSync(folderPath);

LANGUAGE: mjs
CODE:
import fs from 'node:fs';

const folderPath = '/Users/joe';

fs.readdirSync(folderPath);

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
fs.readdirSync(folderPath).map(fileName => {
  return path.join(folderPath, fileName);
});

LANGUAGE: cjs
CODE:
const fs = require('node:fs');

const isFile = fileName => {
  return fs.lstatSync(fileName).isFile();
};

fs.readdirSync(folderPath)
  .map(fileName => {
    return path.join(folderPath, fileName);
  })
  .filter(isFile);

LANGUAGE: mjs
CODE:
import fs from 'node:fs';

const isFile = fileName => {
  return fs.lstatSync(fileName).isFile();
};

fs.readdirSync(folderPath)
  .map(fileName => {
    return path.join(folderPath, fileName);
  })
  .filter(isFile);

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
const obj = {
  x: 0,
  y: 100,
};

const keys = Object.keys(obj); // ['x', 'y']
const values = Object.values(obj); // [0, 100]
const entries = Object.entries(obj); // [['x', 0], ['y', 100]]

TITLE: Stream Pipeline Implementation
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the use of stream.pipeline() API for proper error handling and cleanup in both CommonJS and ES modules formats.

LANGUAGE: cjs
CODE:
const { pipeline } = require('node:stream');
const fs = require('node:fs');
const zlib = require('node:zlib');

pipeline(
  fs.createReadStream('The.Matrix.1080p.mkv'),
  zlib.createGzip(),
  fs.createWriteStream('The.Matrix.1080p.mkv.gz'),
  err => {
    if (err) {
      console.error('Pipeline failed', err);
    } else {
      console.log('Pipeline succeeded');
    }
  }
);

LANGUAGE: mjs
CODE:
import { pipeline } from 'node:stream';
import fs from 'node:fs';
import zlib from 'node:zlib';

pipeline(
  fs.createReadStream('The.Matrix.1080p.mkv'),
  zlib.createGzip(),
  fs.createWriteStream('The.Matrix.1080p.mkv.gz'),
  err => {
    if (err) {
      console.error('Pipeline failed', err);
    } else {
      console.log('Pipeline succeeded');
    }
  }
);

TITLE: Using process.getBuiltinModule() for Conditional Module Loading
DESCRIPTION: Example showing how to conditionally load Node.js built-in modules in ES Modules that need to support other environments, using the new process.getBuiltinModule() function.

LANGUAGE: mjs
CODE:
if (globalThis.process?.getBuiltinModule) {
  // Run in Node.js, use the Node.js fs module.
  const fs = globalThis.process.getBuiltinModule('fs');
  // If `require()` is needed to load user-modules, use createRequire()
  const module = globalThis.process.getBuiltinModule('module');
  const require = module.createRequire(import.meta.url);
  const foo = require('foo');
}

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Implementing Function Chain Pattern in JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates a cleaner approach to handling asynchronous operations using initiator, middleware, and terminator functions.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
function final(someInput, callback) {
  callback(`${someInput} and terminated by executing callback `);
}

function middleware(someInput, callback) {
  return final(`${someInput} touched by middleware `, callback);
}

function initiate() {
  const someInput = 'hello this is a function ';
  middleware(someInput, function (result) {
    console.log(result);
    // requires callback to `return` result
  });
}

initiate();

----------------------------------------

TITLE: File-based Memory Usage Tracking in Node.js
DESCRIPTION: An improved version of the memory tracking script that writes data to a file instead of storing it in memory, preventing memory leaks.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
// script-fix.mjs
import os from 'node:os';
import fs from 'node:fs/promises';

let len = 1_000_000;
const fileName = `entries-${Date.now()}`;

async function addEntry() {
  const entry = {
    timestamp: Date.now(),
    memory: os.freemem(),
    totalMemory: os.totalmem(),
    uptime: os.uptime(),
  };
  await fs.appendFile(fileName, JSON.stringify(entry) + '\n');
}

async function summary() {
  const stats = await fs.lstat(fileName);
  console.log(`File size ${stats.size} bytes`);
}

// execution
(async () => {
  await fs.writeFile(fileName, '----START---\n');
  while (len > 0) {
    await addEntry();
    process.stdout.write(`~~> ${len} entries to record\r`);
    len--;
  }

  await summary();
})();

TITLE: Adding withFileTypes option to fs.readdir
DESCRIPTION: A new boolean option, withFileTypes, can be passed to fs.readdir and fs.readdirSync. If set to true, the methods return an array of directory entries as objects that can be used to determine the type of each entry.

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
const entries = fs.readdirSync('dir', { withFileTypes: true });

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Getting Call Stack Trace with util.getCallSite()
DESCRIPTION: Example demonstrating the new util.getCallSite() API which allows retrieving the current execution stack trace with details like function name, script name, line and column numbers.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
const util = require('node:util');

function exampleFunction() {
  const callSites = util.getCallSite();

  console.log('Call Sites:');
  callSites.forEach((callSite, index) => {
    console.log(`CallSite ${index + 1}:`);
    console.log(`Function Name: ${callSite.functionName}`);
    console.log(`Script Name: ${callSite.scriptName}`);
    console.log(`Line Number: ${callSite.lineNumber}`);
    console.log(`Column Number: ${callSite.column}`);
  });
  // CallSite 1:
  // Function Name: exampleFunction
  // Script Name: /home/example.js
  // Line Number: 5
  // Column Number: 26

  // CallSite 2:
  // Function Name: anotherFunction
  // Script Name: /home/example.js
  // Line Number: 22
  // Column Number: 3

  // ...
}

// A function to simulate another stack layer
function anotherFunction() {
  exampleFunction();
}

anotherFunction();

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Basic WebSocket Connection and Event Handling in Node.js
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates establishing a WebSocket connection and handling basic events including connection opening, message reception, connection closure, and error handling.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
// Creates a new WebSocket connection to the specified URL.
const socket = new WebSocket('ws://localhost:8080');

// Executes when the connection is successfully established.
socket.addEventListener('open', event => {
  console.log('WebSocket connection established!');
  // Sends a message to the WebSocket server.
  socket.send('Hello Server!');
});

// Listen for messages and executes when a message is received from the server.
socket.addEventListener('message', event => {
  console.log('Message from server: ', event.data);
});

// Executes when the connection is closed, providing the close code and reason.
socket.addEventListener('close', event => {
  console.log('WebSocket connection closed:', event.code, event.reason);
});

// Executes if an error occurs during the WebSocket communication.
socket.addEventListener('error', error => {
  console.error('WebSocket error:', error);
});

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Demonstrating Error Propagation Issues in Nested Domains
DESCRIPTION: This example shows the difficulties in propagating errors across nested domains, highlighting limitations in the domain module's error handling capabilities.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
const d1 = domain.create();
d1.foo = true; // custom member to make more visible in console
d1.on('error', er => {
  /* handle error */
});

d1.run(() =>
  setTimeout(() => {
    const d2 = domain.create();
    d2.bar = 43;
    d2.on('error', er => console.error(er.message, domain._stack));
    d2.run(() => {
      setTimeout(() => {
        setTimeout(() => {
          throw new Error('outer');
        });
        throw new Error('inner');
      });
    });
  })
);

TITLE: Using Default Loader for Dynamic Imports in VM
DESCRIPTION: Example of using vm.constants.USE_MAIN_CONTEXT_DEFAULT_LOADER for dynamic imports

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
const { Script, constants } = require('node:vm');
const { resolve } = require('node:path');
const { writeFileSync } = require('node:fs');

// Write test.js and test.txt to the directory where the current script
// being run is located.
writeFileSync(
  resolve(__dirname, 'test.mjs'),
  'export const filename = "./test.json";'
);
writeFileSync(resolve(__dirname, 'test.json'), '{"hello": "world"}');

// Compile a script that loads test.mjs and then test.json
// as if the script is placed in the same directory.
const script = new Script(
  `(async function() {
    const { filename } = await import('./test.mjs');
    return import(filename, { with: { type: 'json' } })
  })();`,
  {
    filename: resolve(__dirname, 'test-with-default.js'),
    importModuleDynamically: constants.USE_MAIN_CONTEXT_DEFAULT_LOADER,
  }
);

// { default: { hello: 'world' } }
script.runInThisContext().then(console.log);

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Formatted Console Logging in Node.js
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to use format specifiers with console.log() to create formatted output in Node.js.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
console.log('My %s has %d ears', 'cat', 2);

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
console.log('%o', Number);

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Writing ServiceWorker Tests in Node.js
DESCRIPTION: Shows an example of writing tests for a ServiceWorker's onActivate function using Node.js's test runner, including mocking of global objects and methods.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
import assert from 'node:assert/strict';
import { describe, mock, it } from 'node:test';

import { onActivate } from './onActivate.js';

describe('ServiceWorker::onActivate()', () => {
  const globalSelf = globalThis.self;
  const claim = mock.fn(async function mock__claim() {});
  const matchAll = mock.fn(async function mock__matchAll() {});

  class ActivateEvent extends Event {
    constructor(...args) {
      super('activate', ...args);
    }
  }

  before(() => {
    globalThis.self = {
      clients: { claim, matchAll },
    };
  });
  after(() => {
    global.self = globalSelf;
  });

  it('should claim all clients', async () => {
    await onActivate(new ActivateEvent());

    assert.equal(claim.mock.callCount(), 1);
    assert.equal(matchAll.mock.callCount(), 1);
  });
});

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Handling REPL Exit Event in JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to add an exit handler to a REPL instance for custom behavior on exit.

LANGUAGE: js
CODE:
local.on('exit', () => {
  console.log('exiting repl');
  process.exit();
});

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Console Count Reset in Node.js
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to use console.countReset() to reset the counter for a specific console.count() label in Node.js.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
const oranges = ['orange', 'orange'];
const apples = ['just one apple'];

oranges.forEach(fruit => {
  console.count(fruit);
});
apples.forEach(fruit => {
  console.count(fruit);
});

console.countReset('orange');

oranges.forEach(fruit => {
  console.count(fruit);
});

LANGUAGE: mjs
CODE:
const res = await fetch('https://nodejs.org/api/documentation.json');
if (res.ok) {
  const data = await res.json();
  console.log(data);
}

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Using New EventEmitter Async Iterator
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the new EventEmitter.on static method for async iteration over events

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
const { on, EventEmitter } = require('events');

(async () => {
  const ee = new EventEmitter();

  // Emit later on
  process.nextTick(() => {
    ee.emit('foo', 'bar');
    ee.emit('foo', 42);
  });

  for await (const event of on(ee, 'foo')) {
    // The execution of this inner block is synchronous and it
    // processes one event at a time (even with await). Do not use
    // if concurrent execution is required.
    console.log(event); // prints ['bar'] [42]
  }
})();

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Configuring Snapshot Tests in Node.js
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to configure snapshot testing in Node.js, including customizing the snapshot file naming convention for better syntax highlighting and ESM compatibility.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
import { basename, dirname, extname, join } from 'node:path';
import { snapshot } from 'node:test';

snapshot.setResolveSnapshotPath(generateSnapshotPath);
/**
 * @param {string} testFilePath '/tmp/foo.test.js'
 * @returns {string} '/tmp/foo.test.snap.cjs'
 */
function generateSnapshotPath(testFilePath) {
  const ext = extname(testFilePath);
  const filename = basename(testFilePath, ext);
  const base = dirname(testFilePath);

  return join(base, `${filename}.snap.cjs`);
}

TITLE: Setting Independent High Water Marks for Duplex Streams
DESCRIPTION: For Duplex streams, the high water mark option can now be set independently for the readable and writable sides.

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
const stream = require('stream');

const duplex = new stream.Duplex({
  readableHighWaterMark: 1024,
  writableHighWaterMark: 2048
});

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Demonstrating Automatic Error Routing in Domain Module
DESCRIPTION: This example shows how a missing 'error' handler allows the active domain to hijack errors, potentially leading to unexpected error handling behavior.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
const domain = require('domain');
const net = require('net');
const d = domain.create();
d.on('error', err => console.error(err.message));

d.run(() =>
  net
    .createServer(c => {
      c.end();
      c.write('bye');
    })
    .listen(8000)
);

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Using the new diagnostics_channel module in Node.js
DESCRIPTION: Example of creating and publishing to a named diagnostics channel

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
const dc = require('diagnostics_channel');
const channel = dc.channel('mysql.query');

MySQL.prototype.query = function query(queryString, values, callback) {
  // Broadcast query information whenever a query is made
  channel.publish({
    query: queryString,
    host: this.hostname,
  });

  this.doQuery(queryString, values, callback);
};

}, 2000);

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Mocking Time in Node.js Tests
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to control time in Node.js tests using the mock.timers functionality, useful for testing time-dependent code without long waits.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
import assert from 'node:assert/strict';
import { describe, it, mock } from 'node:test';

import ago from './ago.mjs';

describe('whatever', { concurrency: true }, () => {
  it('should choose "minutes" when that\'s the closet unit', () => {
    mock.timers.enable({ now: new Date('2000-01-01T00:02:02Z') });

    const t = ago('1999-12-01T23:59:59Z');

    assert.equal(t, '2 minutes ago');
  });
});

LANGUAGE: JSON
CODE:

TITLE: Using assert.partialDeepStrictEqual in Node.js
DESCRIPTION: Examples of using the new assert.partialDeepStrictEqual method for partial deep equality checks in tests.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
assert.partialDeepStrictEqual({ a: 1, b: 2, c: 3 }, { a: 1, b: 2 });

assert.partialDeepStrictEqual([1, 2, 3, 4], [2, 3]);

assert.partialDeepStrictEqual(
  { a: { b: { c: 1, d: 2 } }, e: 3 },
  { a: { b: { c: 1 } } }
);

assert.partialDeepStrictEqual(
  { a: { b: { c: 1, d: 2 } }, e: 3 },
  { a: { b: { c: 1 } } }
);

assert.partialDeepStrictEqual(
  new Set([{ a: 1 }, { b: 1 }]),
  new Set([{ a: 1 }])
);

assert.partialDeepStrictEqual(
  { a: new Set([{ a: 1 }, { b: 1 }]), b: new Map(), c: [1, 2, 3] },
  { a: new Set([{ a: 1 }]), c: [2] }
);

TITLE: Adding writableEnded Property to Writable Streams
DESCRIPTION: Adds a new property writableEnded to writable streams. Its value is set to true after writable.end() has been called.

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
const writable = getWritableStreamSomehow();
writable.end('Hello world', () => {
  console.log(writable.writableEnded); // true
});

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Writing UI Tests with Mocking in Node.js
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to write UI tests for a React component using Node.js's test runner, including mocking module dependencies and handling asynchronous imports.

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
import { before, describe, mock, it } from 'node:test';

import { screen } from '@testing-library/dom';
import { render } from '@testing-library/react'; // Any framework (ex svelte)

// ⚠️ Note that SomeOtherComponent is NOT a static import;
// this is necessary in order to facilitate mocking its own imports.


describe('<SomeOtherComponent>', () => {
  let SomeOtherComponent;
  let calcSomeValue;

  before(async () => {
    // ⚠️ Sequence matters: the mock must be set up BEFORE its consumer is imported.

    // Requires the `--experimental-test-module-mocks` be set.
    calcSomeValue = mock.module('./calcSomeValue.js', { calcSomeValue: mock.fn() });

    ({ SomeOtherComponent } = await import('./SomeOtherComponent.jsx'));
  });

  describe('when calcSomeValue fails', () => {
    // This you would not want to handle with a snapshot because that would be brittle:
    // When inconsequential updates are made to the error message,
    // the snapshot test would erroneously fail
    // (and the snapshot would need to be updated for no real value).

    it('should fail gracefully by displaying a pretty error', () => {
      calcSomeValue.mockImplementation(function mock__calcSomeValue() { return null });

      render(<SomeOtherComponent>);

      const errorMessage = screen.queryByText('unable');

      assert.ok(errorMessage);
    });
  });
});

TITLE: Using New Object Specifiers in util.format()
DESCRIPTION: util.format now supports the %o and %O specifiers for printing objects.

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
const util = require('util');

const obj = { foo: 'bar' };
console.log(util.format('%o', obj)); // Prints compact object representation
console.log(util.format('%O', obj)); // Prints expanded object representation

TITLE: Renaming a Folder in Node.js
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to rename a folder using fs.rename(), fs.renameSync(), and fsPromises.rename(). It includes error handling for each method.

LANGUAGE: cjs
CODE:
const fs = require('node:fs');

fs.rename('/Users/joe', '/Users/roger', err => {
  if (err) {
    console.error(err);
  }
  // done
});

LANGUAGE: mjs
CODE:
import fs from 'node:fs';

fs.rename('/Users/joe', '/Users/roger', err => {
  if (err) {
    console.error(err);
  }
  // done
});

LANGUAGE: cjs
CODE:
const fs = require('node:fs');

try {
  fs.renameSync('/Users/joe', '/Users/roger');
} catch (err) {
  console.error(err);
}

LANGUAGE: mjs
CODE:
import fs from 'node:fs';

try {
  fs.renameSync('/Users/joe', '/Users/roger');
} catch (err) {
  console.error(err);
}

LANGUAGE: cjs
CODE:
const fs = require('node:fs/promises');

async function example() {
  try {
    await fs.rename('/Users/joe', '/Users/roger');
  } catch (err) {
    console.log(err);
  }
}
example();

LANGUAGE: mjs
CODE:
import fs from 'node:fs/promises';

try {
  await fs.rename('/Users/joe', '/Users/roger');
} catch (err) {
  console.log(err);
}

TITLE: Adding New Stream Methods in Node.js

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
// Example usage of new stream methods
const found = await stream.find(x => x > 10);
const array = await stream.toArray();
await stream.forEach(x => console.log(x));
const hasLarge = await stream.some(x => x > 100);
const allSmall = await stream.every(x => x < 10);

TITLE: Instantiating WebAssembly Module in Node.js (CommonJS)
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to read a WebAssembly file, instantiate it, and use an exported function in a CommonJS context. It assumes the existence of an 'add.wasm' file that exports an 'add' function.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
const fs = require('node:fs');

const wasmBuffer = fs.readFileSync('/path/to/add.wasm');

WebAssembly.instantiate(wasmBuffer).then(wasmModule => {
  const { add } = wasmModule.instance.exports;
  const sum = add(5, 6);
  console.log(sum); // Outputs: 11
});

12     age: 'Secret!',
       ~~~

  example.ts:3:5
    3     age: number;
          ~~~
    The expected type comes from property 'age' which is declared here on type 'User'

example.ts:15:7 - error TS2322: Type 'boolean' is not assignable to type 'string'.

15 const isJustineAnAdult: string = isAdult(justine, "I shouldn't be here!");
         ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

example.ts:15:51 - error TS2554: Expected 1 arguments, but got 2.

15 const isJustineAnAdult: string = isAdult(justine, "I shouldn't be here!");
                                                     ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


Found 3 errors in the same file, starting at: example.ts:12

TITLE: XMLHttpRequest with Callback
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates making an XHR request with a callback to handle state changes and response.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
const xhr = new XMLHttpRequest();
xhr.onreadystatechange = () => {
  if (xhr.readyState === 4) {
    xhr.status === 200 ? console.log(xhr.responseText) : console.error('error');
  }
};
xhr.open('GET', 'https://yoursite.com');
xhr.send();

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
import fs from 'node:fs';

fs.stat('/Users/joe/test.txt', (err, stats) => {
  if (err) {
    console.error(err);
  }
  // we have access to the file stats in `stats`
});

  console.error(err);
}

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Dynamically Generating Test Cases in Node.js (pre-v23.8.0)
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to dynamically generate test cases for detecting OS from user agents using Node.js's test runner in versions prior to 23.8.0.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
import assert from 'node:assert/strict';
import { test } from 'node:test';

import { detectOsInUserAgent } from '…';

const userAgents = [
  { ua: '…', os: 'WIN' },
  // …
];

test('Detect OS via user-agent', { concurrency: true }, async t => {
  const cases = userAgents.map(({ os, ua }) => {
    t.test(ua, () => assert.equal(detectOsInUserAgent(ua), os));
  });

  await Promise.allSettled(cases);
});

TITLE: Adding fs.writev Method for Writing Array of Buffers
DESCRIPTION: Introduces fs.writev, fs.writevSync, and filehandle.writev methods to write an array of ArrayBufferViews to a file descriptor.

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
const fs = require('fs');
const buffers = [Buffer.from('Hello '), Buffer.from('world')];
fs.writev(fd, buffers, (err, bytesWritten, buffers) => {
  // Handle callback
});

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Implementing finished() for ReadableStream and WritableStream
DESCRIPTION: The stream module now includes a finished() implementation for ReadableStream and WritableStream, enhancing stream handling capabilities.

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
const { finished } = require('stream/promises');
const readable = getReadableStreamSomehow();
await finished(readable);

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Synchronous File Opening in Node.js (ES Modules)
DESCRIPTION: Shows synchronous file opening using fs.openSync() method in ES Modules format. Returns the file descriptor directly instead of using a callback.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
import fs from 'node:fs';

try {
  const fd = fs.openSync('/Users/joe/test.txt', 'r');
} catch (err) {
  console.error(err);
}

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Custom Protocol Parser Implementation
DESCRIPTION: Example showing how to implement a custom protocol parser using the new Readable stream interface

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
function SimpleProtocol(source, options) {
  if (!(this instanceof SimpleProtocol))
    return new SimpleProtocol(options);

  Readable.call(this, options);
  this._inBody = false;
  this._sawFirstCr = false;

  // source is a readable stream, such as a socket or file
  this._source = source;

  var self = this;
  source.on('end', function() {
    self.push(null);
  });

  // give it a kick whenever the source is readable
  // read(0) will not consume any bytes
  source.on('readable', function() {
    self.read(0);
  });

  this._rawHeader = [];
  this.header = null;
}

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Supporting overriding http/https globalAgent
DESCRIPTION: Adds support for overriding the globalAgent in http and https modules.

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
const http = require('http');
const myAgent = new http.Agent();
http.globalAgent = myAgent;

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Fixed Socket Server with Resume Example
DESCRIPTION: Corrected version of the socket server that properly handles stream flow by calling resume()

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
net.createServer(function(socket) {
  socket.on('end', function() {
    socket.end('I got your message (but didnt read it)\n');
  });

  // start the flow of data, discarding it.
  socket.resume();
}).listen(1337);

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
path.basename(notes, path.extname(notes)); // notes

TITLE: Creating custom require function in Node.js module system

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
const { createRequireFromPath } = require('module');
const requireUtil = createRequireFromPath('/path/to/module.js');

const util = requireUtil('./util');

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Using MockTimers in Node.js test runner
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to use the now stable MockTimers API in the Node.js test runner to set an initial Date object for testing time-based operations.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
import { mock } from 'node:test';
mock.timers.enable({ apis: ['Date'], now: new Date('1970-01-01') });

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Using v8.queryObjects() for Memory Leak Testing
DESCRIPTION: Example demonstrating the new v8.queryObjects() API for searching heap objects by constructor type, useful for memory leak regression testing

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
const { queryObjects } = require('node:v8');
class A {
  foo = 'bar';
}
console.log(queryObjects(A)); // 0
let a = new A();
console.log(queryObjects(A)); // 1
// [ "A { foo: 'bar' }" ]
console.log(queryObjects(A, { format: 'summary' }));

// Release the object.
a = null;
// Search again. queryObjects() includes a full garbage collection
// so a should disappear.
console.log(queryObjects(A)); // 0

class B extends A {
  bar = 'qux';
}
// The child class B's prototype has A's prototype on its prototype chain
// so the prototype object shows up too.
console.log(queryObjects(A, { format: 'summary' })); // [ A {}' ]

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Event Loop Execution Order Example in CommonJS
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates the execution order between setImmediate(), process.nextTick(), and Promise.then() in a CommonJS environment. Shows how different types of asynchronous operations are processed in their respective queues.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
const baz = () => console.log('baz');
const foo = () => console.log('foo');
const zoo = () => console.log('zoo');

const start = () => {
  console.log('start');
  setImmediate(baz);
  new Promise((resolve, reject) => {
    resolve('bar');
  }).then(resolve => {
    console.log(resolve);
    process.nextTick(zoo);
  });
  process.nextTick(foo);
};

start();

// start foo bar zoo baz

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Using crypto.hash() for Fast Hashing
DESCRIPTION: A new helper function crypto.hash() that computes a digest from input in one shot, offering 1.2-2x better performance for smaller inputs compared to createHash()

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
const crypto = require('node:crypto');

// Hashing a string and return the result as a hex-encoded string.
const string = 'Node.js';
// 10b3493287f831e81a438811a1ffba01f8cec4b7
console.log(crypto.hash('sha1', string));

TITLE: Joining Path Components
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to join multiple path segments using path.join() method.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
const name = 'joe';
path.join('/', 'users', name, 'notes.txt'); // '/users/joe/notes.txt'

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Using AbortSignal with child_process.spawn() in JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: Example of using an AbortSignal to abort a spawned child process. Calling .abort() on the controller will stop the process and trigger an AbortError.

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
const controller = new AbortController();
const { signal } = controller;
const grep = spawn('grep', ['ssh'], { signal });
grep.on('error', err => {
  // This will be called with err being an AbortError if the controller aborts
});
controller.abort(); // stops the process

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Version Pinning Strategies
DESCRIPTION: Explains the different version pinning approaches (exact, tilde, caret) and when to use each one for different types of dependencies

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
--save-exact: For tooling and CLI dependencies\n~: For patch updates in dev/test dependencies\n^: For application dependencies requiring latest features

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Using Mock Timers in Node.js Tests
DESCRIPTION: Example demonstrating how to use the new mock timers feature in Node.js test runner to simulate time-based operations synchronously

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
import assert from 'node:assert';
import { test } from 'node:test';

test('mocks setTimeout to be executed synchronously without having to actually wait for it', context => {
  const fn = context.mock.fn();
  // Optionally choose what to mock
  context.mock.timers.enable(['setTimeout']);
  const nineSecs = 9000;
  setTimeout(fn, nineSecs);

  const threeSeconds = 3000;
  context.mock.timers.tick(threeSeconds);
  context.mock.timers.tick(threeSeconds);
  context.mock.timers.tick(threeSeconds);

  assert.strictEqual(fn.mock.callCount(), 1);
});

  // otherwise do things
}, 100);

TITLE: Instantiating WebAssembly Module in Node.js (ES Modules)
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to read a WebAssembly file, instantiate it, and use an exported function in an ES modules context. It uses the fs/promises module for asynchronous file reading.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
import fs from 'node:fs/promises';

const wasmBuffer = await fs.readFile('/path/to/add.wasm');

const wasmModule = await WebAssembly.instantiate(wasmBuffer);

const { add } = wasmModule.instance.exports;

const sum = add(5, 6);

console.log(sum); // Outputs: 11

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Adding Chaining to ESM Loaders in JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: Implements chaining for custom ESM loaders, allowing multiple loaders to be used in sequence. This enhances the flexibility and composability of the ESM loader system.

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
// Example usage of chained ESM loaders
import { load } from 'foo-loader';
import { load as barLoad } from 'bar-loader';

export async function load(url, context, nextLoad) {
  // Custom logic for foo-loader
  return barLoad(url, context, nextLoad);
}

function globalSWBeforeEach() {

}

TITLE: Stream Pipeline Processing in Node.js
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to use Node.js streams pipeline to read a file, compress it using gzip, and write the compressed output to a new file.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
import { pipeline } from 'node:stream/promises';
import { createReadStream, createWriteStream } from 'node:fs';
import { createGzip } from 'node:zlib';

// ensure you have a `package.json` file for this test!
await pipeline
(
  createReadStream('package.json'),
  createGzip(),
  createWriteStream('package.json.gz')
);

// run with `node streams.mjs`

TITLE: File System Temporary Directory Creation Vulnerability (CVE-2023-32003)
DESCRIPTION: Security vulnerability in fs.mkdtemp() and fs.mkdtempSync() missing path validation checks, allowing permission model bypass through path traversal. Affects experimental permission model in Node.js 20.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
fs.mkdtemp()
fs.mkdtempSync()

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Demonstrating UTF-8 Encoding Changes in Node.js
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how the encoding of unmatched surrogate pairs in UTF-8 has changed in the new Node.js releases. It demonstrates the difference in behavior when creating a Buffer from a string containing an unmatched surrogate pair.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
// Prior to these releases:
new Buffer('ab\ud800cd', 'utf8');
// <Buffer 61 62 ed a0 80 63 64>

// After this release:
new Buffer('ab\ud800cd', 'utf8');
// <Buffer 61 62 ef bf bd 63 64>

// This is an explicit conversion to a Buffer, but the implicit
// .write('ab\ud800cd') also results in the same pattern
websocket.write(new Buffer('ab\ud800cd', 'utf8'));
// This would result in the client disconnecting.

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Creating HTTP Server using Node.js CommonJS Modules
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to create a basic HTTP server using Node.js CommonJS module syntax. The server listens on localhost port 3000 and responds with 'Hello World' for all requests.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
const { createServer } = require('node:http');

const hostname = '127.0.0.1';
const port = 3000;

const server = createServer((req, res) => {
  res.statusCode = 200;
  res.setHeader('Content-Type', 'text/plain');
  res.end('Hello World');
});

server.listen(port, hostname, () => {
  console.log(`Server running at http://${hostname}:${port}/`);
});

TITLE: Implementing node --run for Package.json Scripts
DESCRIPTION: Adds a new CLI option to run scripts defined in package.json directly.

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
node --run <script-in-package-json>

----------------------------------------

TITLE: File Reading and Hashing in Node.js
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates reading a file and creating a SHA-1 hash of its contents using Node.js crypto and fs/promises modules.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
import { createHash } from 'node:crypto';
import { readFile } from 'node:fs/promises';

const hasher = createHash('sha1');

hasher.setEncoding('hex');
// ensure you have a `package.json` file for this test!
hasher.write(await readFile('package.json'));
hasher.end();

const fileHash = hasher.read();

// run with `node crypto.mjs`

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Reworking experimental recursive rmdir() in fs module
DESCRIPTION: Changes to the experimental recursive rmdir() function in the fs module, including renaming options and adjusting retry logic.

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
// Changes to fs.rmdir() options:
// - maxBusyTries renamed to maxRetries, default set to 0
// - emfileWait option removed
// - retryDelay option added
// - ENFILE errors now retried

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
const diagnostics_channel = require('diagnostics_channel');
// Improved usage of subscribe/unsubscribe methods

TITLE: Adding TTL option to DNS resolve methods
DESCRIPTION: Implemented `{ttl: true}` option for `dns.resolve4()` and `dns.resolve6()` methods to return TTL values.

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
dns.resolve4('example.com', {ttl: true}, (err, addresses) => {
  // addresses will include TTL values
});

dns.resolve6('example.com', {ttl: true}, (err, addresses) => {
  // addresses will include TTL values 
});

TITLE: Creating a Require Function from File URL in Node.js
DESCRIPTION: New method to create a require function from a file URL. This allows dynamic creation of require functions scoped to specific paths.

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
const { createRequire } = require('module');
const require = createRequire('file:///path/to/module.js');

----------------------------------------

TITLE: SEA (Single Executable Application) Asset Support
DESCRIPTION: Support for embedding and retrieving assets in single executable applications using configuration and new API methods

LANGUAGE: json
CODE:
{
  "main": "/path/to/bundled/script.js",
  "output": "/path/to/write/the/generated/blob.blob",
  "assets": {
    "a.jpg": "/path/to/a.jpg",
    "b.txt": "/path/to/b.txt"
  }
}

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
const { getAsset } = require('node:sea');
// Returns a copy of the data in an ArrayBuffer
const image = getAsset('a.jpg');
// Returns a string decoded from the asset as UTF8.
const text = getAsset('b.txt', 'utf8');
// Returns a Blob containing the asset without copying.
const blob = getAssetAsBlob('a.jpg');

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Updating node-addon-api Package in package.json
DESCRIPTION: Updates the node-addon-api package to a version that addresses the N-API string handling vulnerability. This should be done for projects using native add-ons built with older Node.js versions.

LANGUAGE: json
CODE:
{
  "dependencies": {
    "node-addon-api": "^3.0.0"
  }
}

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
const dns = require('dns/promises');
console.log(dns.NODATA); // Example usage of an exported error code constant

TITLE: Sampling Node.js Execution with DTrace
DESCRIPTION: This DTrace command samples the execution of Node.js processes about 100 times per second for 60 seconds, outputting the results to 'stacks.out'. It can be modified to target a specific process by replacing the execname condition with a pid condition.

LANGUAGE: dtrace
CODE:
dtrace -n 'profile-97/execname == "node" && arg1/{\n    @[jstack(150, 8000)] = count(); } tick-60s { exit(0); }' > stacks.out

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Adding isReadable helper to streams in Node.js

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
const { isReadable } = require('stream');
if (isReadable(someStream)) {
  // Stream is readable
}

TITLE: Demonstrating HTTP Parser Vulnerability in Node.js
DESCRIPTION: A terminal session showing the execution of a proof-of-concept exploit that demonstrates the HTTP parser vulnerability, where private data from one request can be leaked into another request's headers.

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
$ ./node ~/stringptr-update-poc-server.js &
[1] 11801
$ ~/stringptr-update-poc-client.py
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Content-Type: text/plain
Date: Wed, 18 Apr 2012 00:05:11 GMT
Connection: close
Transfer-Encoding: chunked

64
X header:
 This is private data, perhaps an HTTP request with a Cookie in it.
0

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Enhancing util.inspect() Functionality in JavaScript

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
const util = require('util');

const obj = {
  [util.inspect.custom]: function() {
    return 'custom inspection';
  }
};

console.log(util.inspect(obj));

TITLE: Accepting private keys as public keys in crypto
DESCRIPTION: Allows private keys to be used in place of public keys in crypto operations.

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
const crypto = require('crypto');
const { privateKey, publicKey } = crypto.generateKeyPairSync('rsa', {
  modulusLength: 2048,
});
// Can now use privateKey where publicKey is expected

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Function Mocking Example in Node.js Test Runner
DESCRIPTION: Example showing how to use the new function mocking capability in the Node.js test runner via the top-level mock object

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
test('spies on an object method', t => {
  const number = {
    value: 5,
    add(a) {
      return this.value + a;
    },
  };
  t.mock.method(number, 'add');

  assert.strictEqual(number.add(3), 8);
  assert.strictEqual(number.add.mock.calls.length, 1);
});

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Configuring HTTP/2 Session Frame Limit in Node.js
DESCRIPTION: Sets the maximum number of settings in an HTTP/2 session frame to mitigate a DoS vulnerability. This option can be used when initializing an HTTP/2 server or client.

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
const http2 = require('http2');

const server = http2.createServer({
  maxSettings: 32 // Default value, can be adjusted if necessary
});

TITLE: Adding external property to process.memoryUsage()
DESCRIPTION: Added a new `external` property to the object returned by `process.memoryUsage()` to provide information about memory usage of C++ objects bound to JavaScript objects.

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
const memUsage = process.memoryUsage();
console.log(memUsage.external); // New external property

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Fixing Stack Overflow Detection in V8 Isolate
DESCRIPTION: Patch that modifies the stack overflow detection logic in V8's isolate.h file to use real_climit() instead of conditional stack guard checks. This fixes a vulnerability where deep recursive workloads could trigger stack overflows.

LANGUAGE: diff
CODE:
diff --git a/deps/v8/src/isolate.h b/deps/v8/src/isolate.h
index b90191d..2769ca7 100644
--- a/deps/v8/src/isolate.h
+++ b/deps/v8/src/isolate.h
@@ -1392,14 +1392,9 @@ class StackLimitCheck BASE_EMBEDDED {
  public:
   explicit StackLimitCheck(Isolate* isolate) : isolate_(isolate) { }

-  bool HasOverflowed() const {
+  inline bool HasOverflowed() const {
     StackGuard* stack_guard = isolate_->stack_guard();
-    // Stack has overflowed in C++ code only if stack pointer exceeds the C++
-    // stack guard and the limits are not set to interrupt values.
-    // TODO(214): Stack overflows are ignored if a interrupt is pending. This
-    // code should probably always use the initial C++ limit.
-    return (reinterpret_cast<uintptr_t>(this) < stack_guard->climit()) &&
-           stack_guard->IsStackOverflow();
+    return reinterpret_cast<uintptr_t>(this) < stack_guard->real_climit();
   }
  private:
   Isolate* isolate_;

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Using new writableFinished property on writable streams
DESCRIPTION: A new writableFinished property was added to writable streams to indicate that all data has been flushed to the underlying system.

LANGUAGE: JavaScript

const stream = getWritableStreamSomehow();
console.log(stream.writableFinished);

TITLE: Adding throws option to fs sync methods
DESCRIPTION: Adds a throws option to fs.fstatSync, fs.lstatSync, and fs.statSync to return false instead of throwing on errors.

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:
const fs = require('fs');

const stats = fs.statSync('nonexistent.txt', { throwIfNoEntry: false });
console.log(stats); // false

LANGUAGE: JavaScript
CODE:

  // implementation
  return this;
};

crypto.Decipher.prototype.setAAD = function() {
  // implementation  
  return this;
};
